Overview

<text:span text:style-name="T4">Swordfish</text:span> is a cross-platform <text:a xlink:href="#CAT" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T8">CAT</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="#CAT" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a>(<text:span text:style-name="T5">C</text:span>omputer <text:span text:style-name="T5">A</text:span>ided <text:span text:style-name="T5">T</text:span>ranslation) tool based on <text:a xlink:href="#XLIFF" xlink:type="simple">XLIFF</text:a> 1.2 open standard published by <text:a xlink:href="http://www.oasis-open.org/" xlink:type="simple">OASIS</text:a>.

<text:span text:style-name="T4">Swordfish</text:span> supports <text:a xlink:href="#TMX" xlink:type="simple">TMX</text:a> (<text:span text:style-name="T5">T</text:span>ranslation <text:span text:style-name="T5">M</text:span>emory e<text:span text:style-name="T5">X</text:span>change), the vendor-neutral open XML standard for the exchange of <text:a xlink:href="#Translation Memory" xlink:type="simple">Translation Memory</text:a> data created by CAT and localization tools, published by <text:a xlink:href="http://www.lisa.org/" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T8">LISA</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="http://www.lisa.org/" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a>(Localisation Industry Standards Association).
Supported File Formats
The file formats currently supported by <text:span text:style-name="T4">Swordfish</text:span> are:
General documentation types
Software development types
Abiword
Adobe InDesign Interchange
HTML
Microsoft Office 2007
MIF (Maker Interchange Format)
OpenOffice/StarOffice 1.x and 2.x
Plain Text
RTF (Rich Text Format)
Tagged RTF
TTX
XML (Generic)
XML with ready to use configuration files for:
DITA 1.0 and 1.1
DocBook 3.x, 4.x and 5.x
SVG
Word 2003 ML
XHTML
JavaScript
Java Properties
PO (Portable Objects)
RC (Windows C/C++ Resources)
ResX (Windows .NET Resources)
TS (Qt Linguist translation source)
The XLIFF filter for XML supports custom configuration.
Users can define conversion rules for almost any XML vocabulary.
Requirements
Java 1.5 or better from Sun Microsystems is required to run <text:span text:style-name="T4">Swordfish</text:span>.
Java is available as free download from <text:a xlink:href="http://www.java.com/" xlink:type="simple">http://www.java.com</text:a> .
A PC or Mac running at 1GHz or more, with video resolution of at least 1024x768 pixels is recommended.
A minimum of 256MB of free RAM is recommended.
Additional RAM improves speed considerably.
Supported Platforms
<text:span text:style-name="T4">Swordfish</text:span> can be used in the following operating systems:
Microsoft Windows 2000/XP/Vista
Mac OS X 10.4/10.5 (Tiger and Leopard)
Linux with GTK2 (i386 and x86_64)
<text:span text:style-name="T5">Swordfish</text:span> is tested and is known to work in the following Linux distributions:
SUSE Entreprise Linux Desktop 10
openSUSE 10.2/10.3
Fedora Core 8
PCLinuxOS 2007
Ubuntu 7.10
Debian Lenny
Databases
<text:span text:style-name="T5">Swordfish</text:span> includes an <text:span text:style-name="T6">Internal</text:span> database server based on HSQL database engine.
The <text:span text:style-name="T6">Internal</text:span> server is adequate for small databases, but performance degrades with medium or large databases.
It is recommended to use dedicated database engines for databases with more than 10.000 entries.
The supported engines are:
Oracle 10g
MySQL 4.x/5.x
Oracle offers free <text:span text:style-name="T6">Express Editions</text:span> of Oracle 10g for Windows and Linux.
The <text:span text:style-name="T6">Express Edition</text:span> is available for download at:
http://www.oracle.com/technology/software/products/database/xe/index.html
MySQL is a multi-platform database engine that works on Windows, Linux and Mac OS X.
Free versions for non-commercial use are available for download at:
http://dev.mysql.com/downloads/mysql/5.0.html

Detailed instructions for installing Oracle (Windows & Linux) and MySQL 5 (Windows & Mac OS<text:span text:style-name="T2"> </text:span>X) are available at the <text:a xlink:href="http://www.maxprograms.com/tutorials/swordfish.html" xlink:type="simple">Swordfish Tutorials</text:a> section in Maxprograms' web site.
Getting Started
Only a few steps are necessary to translate with <text:span text:style-name="T5">Swordfish</text:span>.
The basic workflow for translating a single document is:
Setup TM and Terminology databases
Convert the source document to XLIFF format
Translate the XLIFF file
Convert the translated XLIFF file to original format
Step 1:
Setup databases

<text:span text:style-name="T5">Swordfish</text:span> uses <text:a xlink:href="#Translation Memory" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T6">Translation Memory</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="#Translation Memory" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a>(TM) technology to assist translators.
It stores your translations in databases and offers them again when you need to translate a similar text.
The first thing you should do is create two databases:
one for holding translations at segment level and another for storing terminology.

To create a database in <text:span text:style-name="T5">Swordfish</text:span>, select <text:span text:style-name="T5">Create Database</text:span> in <text:a xlink:href="#5.2.9. Database Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple">Database</text:a> menu and the following dialog will appear:

<draw:image xlink:actuate="onLoad" xlink:href="Pictures/10000000000001350000017D9F0ED449.jpg" xlink:show="embed" xlink:type="simple"/></draw:frame>Enter a meaningful name for the main TM database in the <text:span text:style-name="T10">Database Name</text:span> text box.
Then select Internal DB in the <text:span text:style-name="T10">Database Type</text:span> drop-down list and finally click on <text:span text:style-name="T5">Create</text:span> button.
A confirmation will appear after the database is created.
Repeat the operation and create a database for storing terms.
Be sure to select a meaningful name for it.
Next, you have to tell the program which database to use for searching translations and which database holds your glossary.

Select the option <text:span text:style-name="T5">Select Reference TM Databases</text:span> in <text:a xlink:href="#3.3.9. Database Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T11">Database</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="#3.3.9. Database Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a>menu and the following dialog will appear:

<draw:image xlink:actuate="onLoad" xlink:href="Pictures/10000000000001A8000001751831E673.jpg" xlink:show="embed" xlink:type="simple"/></draw:frame><text:soft-page-break/>Select the database that will be used for searching translations and click on <text:span text:style-name="T5">Enable Selected DB</text:span> button.

You have to tell<text:span text:style-name="T9"> </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T10">Swordfish</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T9"> where to write your translations when you approve segments; select a database from the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T10">Write-enabled Database</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T9"> drop-down list and then </text:span>click on the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Accept</text:span> button to dismiss the dialog.
You also need to tell the program which database to use when searching terms.

Select the option <text:span text:style-name="T5">Select Reference Terminology Databases</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8"> in </text:span><text:a xlink:href="#3.3.8. Terminology Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T9">Terminology</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="#3.3.8. Terminology Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a><text:span text:style-name="T9">menu to display this dialog:</text:span>

<draw:image xlink:actuate="onLoad" xlink:href="Pictures/10000000000001A800000175164546C8.jpg" xlink:show="embed" xlink:type="simple"/></draw:frame><text:soft-page-break/><text:span text:style-name="T9">Select the database that will be used when searching for terms and click on </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T10">Enable Selected DB</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T9">button.

You also need to tell </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T10">Swordfish</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T9">where to write terms that you add on the fly; select a database from the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T10">Write-enabled Database</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T9">drop-down list and, finally, click on the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T10">Accept</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T9">button to dismiss the dialog.</text:span>
Step 2:
Convert to XLIFF format
<text:span text:style-name="T5">Swordfish</text:span> uses <text:a xlink:href="#XLIFF" xlink:type="simple">XLIFF</text:a> as intermediate format.
Documents need to be converted to XLIFF for translation.

To convert a document to XLIFF format, select <text:span text:style-name="T5">Convert File to XLIFF Format</text:span> in <text:a xlink:href="#4.3.1. File Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple">File</text:a> menu and this dialog will appear:
Enter the source file name in the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Source File</text:span> text box or click the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Browse...
button next to text box to locate it.

The name of the XLIFF file will be automatically inserted in the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">XLIFF File</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8"> text box; adjust it if necessary or use the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Browse...</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8"> button to select a new name for XLIFF file.</text:span>
Swordfish<text:span text:style-name="T8"> tries to detect the file type automatically after you select the source document.
However, in some cases may need to manually select the corresponding type.
<text:span text:style-name="T8">Select the language of the source document using the </text:span>Language<text:span text:style-name="T8"> drop-down list.</text:span>

<text:span text:style-name="T8">Verify the </text:span><text:a xlink:href="#Character Set" xlink:type="simple">Character Set</text:a><text:span text:style-name="T8"> selected by </text:span>Swordfish<text:span text:style-name="T8"> and make any necessary adjustment.</text:span>

<text:soft-page-break/><text:span text:style-name="T8">Leave the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Open XLIFF File After Conversion</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">check box selected and click on the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Convert to XLIFF</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">button.
</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Swordfish</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">will generate an XLIFF file and open it when finished.</text:span>
Step 3:
Translate the XLIFF file
Select the Target text box in the <text:a xlink:href="#4.1.2.Translation Panel|outline" xlink:type="simple">Translation Panel</text:a> and start typing your translation.
Source formatting is represented with green marks with a number (i<text:span text:style-name="T16">.e.</text:span>:
<text:span text:style-name="T13">«6»</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T14">)</text:span> in source text.

To insert green marks, also known as <text:span text:style-name="T6">tags</text:span>, press <text:span text:style-name="User_20_Entry"><text:span text:style-name="T11">Ctrl +</text:span></text:span><text:span text:style-name="User_20_Entry"> </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T6">N</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T11"></text:span><text:span text:style-name="T6">, </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T11">where </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T6">N</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T11"> is the number in the mark.

You can also use the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T10">Insert Tag</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T11"> button from the </text:span><text:a xlink:href="#4.1.2.Translation Panel|outline" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T11">Translation Panel</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="#4.1.2.Translation Panel|outline" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a><text:span text:style-name="T11">to display a dialog that asks for a tag number or one of the the Insert Tag options from </text:span><text:a xlink:href="#4.3.2. Edit Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T11">Edit Menu</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="#4.3.2. Edit Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a><text:a xlink:href="#4.3.2. Edit Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T12">.</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="#4.3.2. Edit Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a>

<text:span text:style-name="T20">When the segment is fully translated, press </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T18"></text:span><text:span text:style-name="User_20_Entry"><text:span text:style-name="T17">Ctrl + E</text:span></text:span><text:span text:style-name="User_20_Entry"></text:span><text:span text:style-name="T18"> </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T20">or click on the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T21">A</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T22">pproved </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T20">check box that is below the target.
When you approve the segment, its translation is stored in the selected Default TM Database and is also automatically propagated to all similar unapproved segments.

<text:span text:style-name="T20">Use</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T18"></text:span><text:span text:style-name="User_20_Entry"><text:span text:style-name="T17">PgUp</text:span></text:span><text:span text:style-name="User_20_Entry"></text:span><text:span text:style-name="T18"> </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T20">and</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T18"></text:span><text:span text:style-name="User_20_Entry"><text:span text:style-name="T17">PgDn</text:span></text:span><text:span text:style-name="User_20_Entry"></text:span><text:span text:style-name="T18"> </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T20">keys or the blue arrows in the </text:span><text:a xlink:href="#4.1.2.Translation Panel|outline" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T20">Translation Panel</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="#4.1.2.Translation Panel|outline" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a><text:span text:style-name="T20">to move to the next or </text:span><text:a xlink:href="#4.3.2. Edit Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T15">previous segments and translate them.</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="#4.3.2. Edit Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a>

When all segments have been translated, press <text:span text:style-name="User_20_Entry"><text:span text:style-name="T11">F5</text:span></text:span> or use the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Preview Translation</text:span> option from <text:a xlink:href="#4.3.10. QA Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple">QA Menu</text:a> to review your translations.
Note any segment with errors and correct them.

To visit a segment knowing its number, you can type the number in the text box that contains current segment number (the one between the blue arrows) and press <text:span text:style-name="User_20_Entry"><text:span text:style-name="T11">Enter</text:span></text:span><text:span text:style-name="User_20_Entry"></text:span>.

Finally, use the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Tag Analysis</text:span> option from <text:a xlink:href="#4.3.10. QA Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple">QA Menu</text:a> to check that your file is properly translated.
Pay special attention to errors in tags, because the translated document may become unusable.
Step 4:
Convert XLIFF file to original format
The last step in the translation process is the generation of the translated document.

To achieve it, select <text:span text:style-name="T5">Convert XLIFF File to Original Format</text:span> in <text:a xlink:href="#4.3.1. File Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple">File Menu</text:a> and this dialog will appear:

<draw:image xlink:actuate="onLoad" xlink:href="Pictures/10000000000001AC000001CA72639407.jpg" xlink:show="embed" xlink:type="simple"/></draw:frame><text:span text:style-name="T5">Swordfish</text:span> automatically offers to convert the XLIFF file that is currently open.

If the <text:span text:style-name="T5">XLIFF File</text:span> text box is empty or you want to convert a different file, type the name of the XLIFF file in the top text box or use the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Browse...</text:span> button next to it to locate the XLIFF file.
Check the name of the translated file proposed by <text:span text:style-name="T5">Swordfish</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8"> and adjust it if necessary.

You can use </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8">the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Browse...</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8"> button to select a different name or location.</text:span>

<text:soft-page-break/><text:span text:style-name="T8">Finally, click on </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Convert File to Original Format</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">button and </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Swordfish</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">will generate the translated document and will open it with the default application if the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Open File After Conversion</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">check box is selected.</text:span>
Working with Projects

<text:span text:style-name="T8">Projects are sets of related files that </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Swordfish</text:span> lets you process as one entity, facilitating the conversion to and from XLIFF format and the generation of unified word counts.
The basic steps for working with projects are:
Create a project
Convert project files to XLIFF format
Convert project files to original format
Create a project

To create a project in <text:span text:style-name="T5">Swordfish</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8"> select</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T5">Create New Project</text:span> option in <text:a xlink:href="#4.3.3. Project Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple">Project</text:a> menu and a file selection dialog will appear.
Enter a name for the new project file, using <text:span text:style-name="T11">.xlp</text:span> as file extension.
An empty project will be created and the following dialog will appear:

<draw:image xlink:actuate="onLoad" xlink:href="Pictures/100000000000030D0000023B169FCF4B.jpg" xlink:show="embed" xlink:type="simple"/></draw:frame>You need to configure all <text:span text:style-name="T5">Default Properties</text:span> before adding files to a project.
Start by selecting a <text:span text:style-name="T5">File Format</text:span> for the first set of files that you will add .
Set languages and source character set and then click on <text:span text:style-name="T5">Add File(s)</text:span> button.
A file selection dialog will let you incorporate one or more files to the project.

You can add files of different formats to the project; if required, change <text:span text:style-name="T5">File Format</text:span> and <text:span text:style-name="T5">Source Character Set</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8"> and add more files to the project.</text:span>
<text:span text:style-name="T8">You can specify additional </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">File Options</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">for each file in a project.
These options are:
<text:span text:style-name="T5">Store File in</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">:
lets you select the folder where XLIFF files will be stored during conversion process.
<text:span text:style-name="T5">Store Translated Files in</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">:
lets you select the folder where target documents will be placed </text:span><text:soft-page-break/><text:span text:style-name="T8">when project files are converted to original format.</text:span>
<text:span text:style-name="T5">Target Files Prefix</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">:
lets you select a prefix that will be added before the file extension to target documents when project files are converted to original format.
<text:span text:style-name="T5">Target File Suffix</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">:
lets you select a suffix that will be added to target documents when project files are converted to original format.

<text:span text:style-name="T8">You can modify the properties of an individual file at any time by selecting it on the table and clicking on the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Configure Selected File</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">button.</text:span>

<text:span text:style-name="T8">You can also remove any file from a project by selecting it on the top table and clicking on the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Remove File</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">button.</text:span>

<text:span text:style-name="T8">Click on the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Accept</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">button to save the changes done to the project and dismiss the dialog.</text:span>
Convert project files to XLIFF format

To convert all files in a project to XLIFF format select <text:span text:style-name="T5">Convert Project Files to XLIFF Format</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8"> from </text:span><text:a xlink:href="#4.3.3. Project Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T8">Project</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="#4.3.3. Project Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a><text:span text:style-name="T8">menu and the following dialog will appear:</text:span>

<draw:image xlink:actuate="onLoad" xlink:href="Pictures/100000000000019700000249EEF36F52.jpg" xlink:show="embed" xlink:type="simple"/></draw:frame>Enter the name of the project file in the top text box or use the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Browse...</text:span> button next to it to select a file.
Select the appropriate segmentation options and the <text:a xlink:href="#SRX" xlink:type="simple">SRX</text:a> (Segmentation Rules eXchange) file to use during the conversion process.

Use the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Reference TM Databases</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8"> button to specify the databases to apply to the XLIFF files if you enable the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Add Translation</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8"> option.</text:span>

<text:span text:style-name="T8">Check the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Merge Project Files</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">box if you want to combine the individual XLIFF files into a larger one.
You need to select a name for the combined XLIFF file if you enable this option.

<text:span text:style-name="T8">Finally, click on the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Convert Files</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">button to start the conversion process.</text:span>
Convert project files to original format
After translating either individual XLIFF files or a merged XLIFF, you need to convert them back to original format.

Select <text:span text:style-name="T5">Convert Project Files to Original Format</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8"> from </text:span><text:a xlink:href="#4.3.3. Project Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T8">Project</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="#4.3.3. Project Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a><text:span text:style-name="T8">menu to display this </text:span><text:soft-page-break/><text:span text:style-name="T8">dialog:</text:span>

<draw:image xlink:actuate="onLoad" xlink:href="Pictures/10000000000001B6000000EA375A5E38.jpg" xlink:show="embed" xlink:type="simple"/></draw:frame>Enter the name of the project file in the top text box or use the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Browse...</text:span> button next to it to select a file.

Select the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Store Translations in TM Database</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8"> option if you want to</text:span> import all approved translations into a TM database during conversion process.
When this option is enabled you must select a database from the drop-down list.

<text:span text:style-name="T8">Finally, click on the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Convert Files to Original Format </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8">button to start the conversion process.</text:span>
Merge/Split project files

You can merge the individual XLIFF files of a project into a larger one by using the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Merge Project Files</text:span> option from <text:a xlink:href="#4.3.3. Project Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple">Project</text:a> menu.

<draw:image xlink:actuate="onLoad" xlink:href="Pictures/1000000000000198000000BBA65D8F17.jpg" xlink:show="embed" xlink:type="simple"/></draw:frame>Enter the name of the project file in the top text box or use the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Browse...</text:span> button next to it to select a file.
Enter the name of the combined XLIFF file or use the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Browse...</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8"> button to select a file.</text:span>
<text:span text:style-name="T8">Click on the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Merge Files</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">button to start the merge operation.</text:span>

<text:span text:style-name="T8">Once the combined XLIFF file has been translated, you need to split it before </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8">converting the project </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8">files to original format.

Use the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Split XLIFF File</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">option from the </text:span><text:a xlink:href="#4.3.3. Project Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T8">Project</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="#4.3.3. Project Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a><text:span text:style-name="T8">menu to regenerate the individual XIFF files.</text:span>
Repetition Analysis

Select <text:span text:style-name="T5">Repetition Analysis</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8"> option from </text:span><text:a xlink:href="#4.3.3. Project Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T8">Project</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="#4.3.3. Project Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a><text:span text:style-name="T8">menu to generate a web page with detailed statistics showing word counts, TM matches and translation status for a project.
The analysis is automatically displayed using the default web browser when the report generation is completed.
User Interface
The following picture portrays Swordfish:
Panels

Swordfish's User Interface consists of several individual floating re-sizable panels that the user can hide or show using the <text:a xlink:href="#1.2.4. View Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T6">View</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="#1.2.4. View Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a>menu.
Main Panel
The <text:span text:style-name="T6">Main Panel</text:span> holds the application menu (except on Mac OS X) and the main tool bar, with icons for accessing the most usual features.
Closing this panel closes the application.
Translation Panel
The <text:span text:style-name="T6">Translation Panel</text:span> is where the user types or reviews the translations of the open XLIFF file.
The panel contains the following sections:
Source text
Target text
Context areas
Buttons area
Information area
Current segment number is displayed in a text box, near the bottom left, that looks like this:
Clicking on the arrows allows moving to the previous and following segments.
By typing a number in the text box and pressing Enter, the selected segment is displayed.
The amount of context information displayed by the program is controlled using the context text box:
Use the <text:span text:style-name="T6">Approved</text:span> check box to mark the status of the segment as approved or unapproved.
Buttons:
Copy text and tags from source text box to target text box.
Display a dialog for entering the tag number to insert in target text.
Check the spelling of current translation and display a dialog for correcting errors if necessary.
Edit source text.
Accept the changes done to source text.
This button is disabled unless source is being edited.
Reject the changes done to source text.
This button is disabled unless source is being edited.
Display or hide a panel containing translation notes.
Display a dialog for selecting the segments that will be visible in the translation panel.
Toggle <text:span text:style-name="T6">Translation Panel</text:span> layout between side by side and top/bottom.
TM Matches

<draw:image xlink:actuate="onLoad" xlink:href="Pictures/10000000000001640000012B2E3C91BA.jpg" xlink:show="embed" xlink:type="simple"/></draw:frame>The <text:span text:style-name="T6">TM Matches</text:span> panel contains suggested translations extracted from TM databases or automatically propagated at translation time.
Buttons:
Copy the foremost translation from the <text:span text:style-name="T6">TM Matches</text:span> panel to target text box.
Copy the foremost translation from the <text:span text:style-name="T6">TM Matches</text:span> panel to target text box, excluding all tags.
Add a mark to the corresponding database entry of the translation displayed in the TM Matches panel.

The displayed <text:span text:style-name="T6">Origin</text:span> of an entry indicates the name of the database from which the match was extracted or autoFuzzy if the match was propagated from another segment within the document.
Auto-Translation

<draw:image xlink:actuate="onLoad" xlink:href="Pictures/1000000000000165000000C61685019A.jpg" xlink:show="embed" xlink:type="simple"/></draw:frame>The <text:span text:style-name="T6">Auto-Translation</text:span> panel contains matches assembled using terms extracted from Reference Terminology databases and, whenever possible, TM matches already present in the segment.
Buttons:
Copy the foremost translation from the <text:span text:style-name="T6">Auto-Translation</text:span> panel to target text box.
Copy the foremost translation from the <text:span text:style-name="T6">Auto-Translation</text:span> panel to target text box, excluding all tags.
Terminology

<draw:image xlink:actuate="onLoad" xlink:href="Pictures/1000000000000163000000C89E92BA8B.jpg" xlink:show="embed" xlink:type="simple"/></draw:frame>The <text:span text:style-name="T6">Terminology</text:span> panel contains the terms from source text and their corresponding translations into the target language that are found in the enabled Reference Terminology databases.
Buttons:
Copy the translation of the selected term to the target text box.
Notes

<draw:image xlink:actuate="onLoad" xlink:href="Pictures/100000000000014C000000D3DD3DAF9E.jpg" xlink:show="embed" xlink:type="simple"/></draw:frame>The <text:span text:style-name="T6">Notes</text:span> panel contains notes entered at translation time by the translator and notes generated by the XLIFF filters at conversion time.
The filters for TTX and Tagged RTF formats preserve in notes the match quality of segments pre-translated with other CAT tools.
Buttons:
Display a dialog for adding notes to current segment.
Display a dialog for editing the selected note.
Remove the selected note.
