Databases
<text:span text:style-name="T5">Swordfish</text:span> uses <text:a xlink:href="#Translation Memory" xlink:type="simple">Translation Memory</text:a> (TM) technology to assist translators.
It stores your translations in databases and offers them again when you need to translate a similar text.
<text:span text:style-name="T5">Swordfish</text:span> includes an <text:span text:style-name="T6">Internal</text:span> database server based on HSQL database engine.
The <text:span text:style-name="T6">Internal</text:span> server is adequate for small databases, but performance degrades with medium or large databases.
It is recommended to use dedicated database engines for databases with more than 10.000 entries.
The supported engines are:
Oracle 10g
MySQL 4.x/5.x
Database Creation

To create a database in <text:span text:style-name="T5">Swordfish</text:span>, select <text:span text:style-name="T5">Create Database</text:span> in <text:a xlink:href="#1.3.9. Database Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T11">Database</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="#1.3.9. Database Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a>menu and the following dialog will appear:
Enter a database name in the top text box.
Database names can only contain a combination of characters from A to Z (lower and upper case) and numbers.
Do not use punctuation marks or spaces in a name.
Select a <text:span text:style-name="T5">Database Type</text:span> from the drop-down list.
Available options are:
Internal DB:<text:span text:style-name="T8"> embedded database server based on HSQL database.</text:span>
MySQL 4.x:<text:span text:style-name="T8"> open source database engine, free for non commercial use.
Available for Windows, Linux and Mac OS X.
MySQL 5.x<text:span text:style-name="T8">:
open source database engine, free for non commercial use.
Available for Windows, Linux and Mac OS X.
Oracle 10g<text:span text:style-name="T8">:
commercial database engine available for Windows, Linux and Mac </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8">OS X Server.
Free </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T7">Express Edition</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8"> available.
For database server other than Internal DB you need to fill these fields:
Instance/DB
Name of the Oracle server instance that will hold the database.
Default instance name for Oracle Express is XE
Server Name
Name or IP address of the database server
Port Number
TCP port used by the database engine to listen requests.
<text:span text:style-name="T5">Swordfish</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8"> offers the default values automatically when a Database Type is selected.</text:span>
User Name
Name of a user with privileges for creating a database.
Password
Password used to authenticate the user in the database engine.
Select the desired optimization option:
Match Quality:
provides most matches by aggressively indexing text at syllable/byte level.
Speed:
provides less matches at a higher speed by indexing text at word level.
<text:span text:style-name="T8">Finally, click on </text:span>Create<text:span text:style-name="T8"> button to create the database.</text:span>
Using Databases
The basic operations that you need to perform in everyday use are:
Import of TM and terminology data
Export data for exchange
Selection of working databases for regular TM and terminology.
Importing data
Swordfish<text:span text:style-name="T8"> lets you import two categories of data:
regular TM data and terminology data.
TM data can be imported in 2 formats:

<text:a xlink:href="#TMX" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T8">TMX</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="#TMX" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a><text:span text:style-name="T8">(Translation Memory eXchange)</text:span>

<text:a xlink:href="#CSV" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T8">CSV</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="#CSV" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a><text:span text:style-name="T8">(Comma Separated Values)</text:span>
Terminology data can be imported in these formats:
TMX  aligned sets of terms in two or more languages
CSV  aligned sets of terms with no attributes
<text:a xlink:href="#TBX" xlink:type="simple">TBX</text:a> (TermBase eXchange)  aligned sets of terms in two or more languages with support for advanced terminological information
Import TMX Files

To import a TMX files select <text:span text:style-name="T5">Import TMX File</text:span> option from <text:a xlink:href="#5.2.9. Database Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple">Database</text:a> menu and this dialog will appear:

<draw:image xlink:actuate="onLoad" xlink:href="Pictures/10000000000001A7000001799E681ED0.jpg" xlink:show="embed" xlink:type="simple"/></draw:frame>Enter the name of the file to import in the top text box or use the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Browse...</text:span> button to locate it.
<text:soft-page-break/>Select the database that you want to use for holding the imported data using the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Database Name</text:span> drop-down list.
Choose an import option:
Append Entries:
segments are imported without checking for duplicates or similar previous entries.
Update Existing Similar Entries:
the program searches for duplicates or similar existing segments and updates them in the database.
The TMX file must have source language set to a real language code, not *all*.
You can optionally associate your TM data to a given project, customer or subject at import time.
Enter new project details or select them from the drop-down lists.
<text:span text:style-name="T8">Finally, click on the </text:span>Import TMX File<text:span text:style-name="T8"> button to start the import process.</text:span>
Import CSV Files
CSV (Comma Separated Values) is a standard format for storing tabular data.
Before importing a CSV file you need to know certain details about it:
Column Separator:
the character used to separate data columns in the CSV file.
The most common separators are comma and tab characters.
Text Delimiter:
characters used to enclose column data.
Delimiters are used when the data can contain the character used as column separator.
Character Set:<text:span text:style-name="T8"> the encoding used for writing the CSV file.
The most common options are:
UTF-16, UTF-8 and Windows-1252.
Use a text editor to examine the CSV file and obtain the necessary details.

<text:span text:style-name="T8">To import a CSV files select </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Import CSV File</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">option from </text:span><text:a xlink:href="#5.2.9. Database Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T8">Database</text:span></text:a><text:span text:style-name="T8"> menu and this dialog will appear:</text:span>
Enter the name of the file to import in the top text box or use the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Browse...</text:span> button to locate it.
Set the properties of the CSV file.
You can either type the separator characters or select them from the drop down lists.
Select the database that you want to use for holding the imported data using the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Database </text:span>drop-down list.
Use the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Add Language</text:span> button to display a dialog where you will select the language code for each column.
<text:span text:style-name="T8">Finally, click on the </text:span>Import CSV File<text:span text:style-name="T8"> button to start the import process.</text:span>
Import TBX Files

Select <text:span text:style-name="T5">Import TBX File</text:span> option from <text:a xlink:href="#5.2.9. Database Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple">Database</text:a> menu and the following dialog will appear:

<draw:image xlink:actuate="onLoad" xlink:href="Pictures/10000000000001A7000000C32921B29E.jpg" xlink:show="embed" xlink:type="simple"/></draw:frame>Enter the name of the file to import in the top text box or use the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Browse...</text:span> button to locate it.
Select the database that you want to use for holding the imported data using the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Database Name </text:span>drop-down list.
<text:span text:style-name="T8">Finally, click on the </text:span>Import TBX File<text:span text:style-name="T8"> button to start the import process.</text:span>
Exporting data
<text:span text:style-name="T5">Swordfish</text:span> lets you export your databases as TMX files, either individually or as a group of files.
Export individual databases

To export one database as a TMX file, select <text:span text:style-name="T5">Export Database as TMX</text:span> option from <text:a xlink:href="#5.2.9. Database Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple">Database</text:a> menu and the following dialog will appear:

<draw:image xlink:actuate="onLoad" xlink:href="Pictures/10000000000001A7000001A8F96D0612.jpg" xlink:show="embed" xlink:type="simple"/></draw:frame>Select the database to export using the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Database Name</text:span> drop-down list.
Enter a name for the TMX file in the top text box or use the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Browse...</text:span> button next to it to select a location.
Optionally, select the languages that you want to export in the languages list.
Press and hold the Ctrl key when clicking languages to select multiple options.
Check the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Export as TMX Level 1 (No Tags)</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8"> box if you don't want to export formatting codes from your database.
This may help improving reuse of your TM data in other CAT tools.

<text:span text:style-name="T8">Check the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Export Flagged Segments Only</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">box if you want to export only segments that you flagged at translation time using the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Flag Matching Translation in TM Database</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">button in </text:span><text:a xlink:href="#5.1.3.TM Matches|outline" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T8">TM Matches</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="#5.1.3.TM Matches|outline" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a><text:span text:style-name="T8">panel.</text:span>
Select the source language for your TMX file using the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Source Language</text:span> drop-down list.
Notice that only CAT tools that can translate in any direction support the standard <text:span text:style-name="T5">*all*</text:span> option.
Some translation tools only support TMX files with 2 languages and require one of them to be marked as source language.
You can use the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Set Export Filters</text:span> to display a dialog that allows you to select the TM data that you want to export.
You can filter your TM data on these criteria:
Project
Customer
Subject
Finally, click on the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Export</text:span> button to start the export process.
Export a group of databases

You can export all databases or a group of selected databases at once by selecting <text:span text:style-name="T5">Export all Databases as TMX</text:span> option from <text:a xlink:href="#5.2.9. Database Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple">Database</text:a> menu.
The export all databases dialog looks like this:
All databases are exported by default.
You can select the databases to export pressing and holding the <text:span text:style-name="Source_20_Text">Ctrl</text:span> key while you click on the relevant row of the database list.

<text:soft-page-break/>Enter the name of a folder where <text:span text:style-name="T5">Swordfish</text:span> will store the TMX files for each database in the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Output Folder</text:span> text box or use the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Browse...</text:span> button next to it to select a location.
Finally, click on the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Export</text:span> button to start the export process.
Database selection
Swordfish allows you to work with two database types:

<text:span text:style-name="T5">TM databases:</text:span> databases that contain translations of full segments and are used to provide matches at segment level, which are displayed in the <text:a xlink:href="#5.1.3.TM Matches|outline" xlink:type="simple">TM Matches</text:a> panel

Terminology databases:<text:span text:style-name="T8"> databases that contain term pairs, displayed in the </text:span><text:a xlink:href="#5.1.5.Terminology|outline" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T8">Terminology</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="#5.1.5.Terminology|outline" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a><text:span text:style-name="T8">panel, and that can be used by the Auto-Translation engine to compose matches combining regular TM data and terms.</text:span>

<text:span text:style-name="T8">Use the </text:span>Select Reference TM Databases<text:span text:style-name="T8"> option from </text:span><text:a xlink:href="#5.2.9. Database Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T8">Database</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="#5.2.9. Database Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a><text:span text:style-name="T8">menu to configure your TM databases in this dialog:</text:span>

<draw:image xlink:actuate="onLoad" xlink:href="Pictures/10000000000001A8000001751831E673.jpg" xlink:show="embed" xlink:type="simple"/></draw:frame>Select the databases that will be used for searching translations and click on <text:span text:style-name="T5">Enable Selected DB</text:span> button.
Press and hold the <text:span text:style-name="Source_20_Text">Ctrl</text:span> key while clicking on the database list to select multiple entries at a time.

<text:span text:style-name="T9">To tell </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T10">Swordfish</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T9">where to write your translations when you approve segments, select a database from the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T10">Write-enabled Database</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T9">drop-down list.

<text:span text:style-name="T9">Use the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T10">Set Match Penalty</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T9">button to assign a penalty to a selected database in a special dialog.
That penalty will be deducted from the match quality value of all matches extracted from the affected database.
Click on the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Accept</text:span> button to dismiss the dialog and store your preferences.

<text:span text:style-name="T8">Use the </text:span>Select Reference Terminology Databases<text:span text:style-name="T8"> option from </text:span><text:a xlink:href="#5.2.8. Terminology Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T8">Terminology</text:span></text:a><text:span text:style-name="T8"> menu to configure </text:span><text:soft-page-break/><text:span text:style-name="T8">your terminology databases in this dialog:</text:span>

Select the databases that will be used for searching terms to display in the <text:a xlink:href="#5.1.5.Terminology|outline" xlink:type="simple">Terminology</text:a> panel or to be used by the Auto-Translation engine and click on the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Enable Selected DB</text:span> button.
Press and hold the <text:span text:style-name="Source_20_Text">Ctrl</text:span> key while clicking on the database list to select multiple entries at a time.

<text:span text:style-name="T9">To tell </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T10">Swordfish</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T9">where to write terms that you add on the fly, select a database from the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T10">Write-enabled Database</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T9">drop-down list.
Click on the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Accept</text:span> button to dismiss the dialog and store your preferences.
Configuration Options
Swordfish<text:span text:style-name="T8"> is a fully configurable application.

You can customize </text:span>Swordfish<text:span text:style-name="T8"> using the options available in </text:span><text:a xlink:href="#4.3.6. Options Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T8">Options</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="#4.3.6. Options Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a><text:span text:style-name="T8">and </text:span><text:a xlink:href="#4.3.11. Advanced Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T8">Advanced</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="#4.3.11. Advanced Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a><text:span text:style-name="T8">menus.</text:span>
Language Settings
Swordfish's<text:span text:style-name="T8"> graphical user interface (GUI) is available in the following languages:</text:span>
English
Polish
Portuguese
Portuguese (Brazilian)
Russian
Spanish
Turkish
Ukrainian

<text:span text:style-name="T8">Use the </text:span>Language<text:span text:style-name="T8"> sub-menu of </text:span><text:a xlink:href="#4.3.6. Options Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple">Options</text:a><text:span text:style-name="T8"> menu to select the language used by </text:span>Swordfih's<text:span text:style-name="T8"> GUI.</text:span>

<text:span text:style-name="T8">Translations were gently provided by the </text:span><text:a xlink:href="http://www.swordfish-localization.net/" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T8">Swordfish Localization Project</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="http://www.swordfish-localization.net/" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a><text:span text:style-name="T8">.</text:span>
Keyboard Shortcuts

Select <text:span text:style-name="T5">Shortcuts Configuration</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8"> in </text:span><text:a xlink:href="#4.3.6. Options Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T8">Options</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="#4.3.6. Options Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a><text:span text:style-name="T8">menu and this dialog will appear:</text:span>
The picture on the left side shows the dialog for Windows or Linux.

The picture on the right side shows the dialog on Mac OS X, which includes support for the standard </text:span><text:span text:style-name="Source_20_Text"><text:span text:style-name="T8">Cmd</text:span></text:span><text:span text:style-name="Source_20_Text"></text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8"> (Command) key.</text:span>
All commands available in the different menus are listed in the Shortcuts Configuration dialog.
They are included in the order they have inside the menus.

<text:span text:style-name="T8">Use the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Save</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">button to save any custom changes you do and the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Load Defaults</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">button to restore the original shortcuts shipped with the program.</text:span>
Default Applications

<text:span text:style-name="T8">By default, </text:span>Swordfish<text:span text:style-name="T8"> uses the applications registered at operating system level to open files of </text:span><text:soft-page-break/><text:span text:style-name="T8">diverse types.

Users can tell </text:span>Swordfish<text:span text:style-name="T8"> to use different applications to open certain file types with </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8">the </text:span>Default Viewers<text:span text:style-name="T8"> option from </text:span><text:a xlink:href="#4.3.6. Options Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T8">Options</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="#4.3.6. Options Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a><text:span text:style-name="T8">menu.
The Default Viewers dialog has two parts:
The top part contains a list of document types and their default extensions.
To add a new document type click on the </text:span>Add<text:span text:style-name="T8"> button and the following window will appear:</text:span>

<draw:image xlink:actuate="onLoad" xlink:href="Pictures/1000000000000128000000B3FE9158CC.jpg" xlink:show="embed" xlink:type="simple"/></draw:frame><text:span text:style-name="T8">Type a description and an extension in the provided text boxes and click on the </text:span>Accept<text:span text:style-name="T8"> button to save the new document type.</text:span>
The bottom part contains a list of applications that can be used to open the document type selected in the list that appears at top.
The program selected to open files with the selected extension appears with an asterisk on the lower table.
To add a new handler for the selected file type, click on the </text:span>Add<text:span text:style-name="T8"> button of the bottom row and this dialog will appear:</text:span>
Enter a descriptive application name in the top text box and the name to the executable in the lower text box.
You can use the </text:span>Browse...<text:span text:style-name="T8"> button to locate the application in the file system.
Click on the </text:span>Accept<text:span text:style-name="T8"> button to add the application to the list of viewers.</text:span>
Language Codes

<text:span text:style-name="T5">Swordfish</text:span> uses by default language and country codes in the formats recommended by ISO<text:span text:style-name="T2"> </text:span>639-1, ISO<text:span text:style-name="T2"> </text:span>639-2 and ISO<text:span text:style-name="T2"> </text:span>3166-1 specifications.

Language codes should normally have the formats xx-YY or xxx-YY where xx or xxx are language codes in lower case (as established by ISO<text:span text:style-name="T2"> </text:span>639-1 and ISO<text:span text:style-name="T2"> </text:span>639-2) and YY is an optional country code in capitals, as prescribed by ISO<text:span text:style-name="T2"> </text:span>3166-1 specification.

<text:soft-page-break/>For compatibility with other applications, <text:span text:style-name="T5">Swordfish</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8"> allows changing language codes to other </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8">formats, like XX-YY (all capitals).

To change a language code or to add a new one to the list of supported languages, select </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Language Codes</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8"> from </text:span><text:a xlink:href="#4.3.6. Options Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T8">Options</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="#4.3.6. Options Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a><text:span text:style-name="T8">menu and this dialog will appear:</text:span>

<draw:image xlink:actuate="onLoad" xlink:href="Pictures/1000000000000210000001AC29C1D5E7.jpg" xlink:show="embed" xlink:type="simple"/></draw:frame> <text:span text:style-name="T8">Click the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Add Language</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">button to add a new entry to the list and the following dialog </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8">will appear:</text:span>
Enter a code and a name for the language.
Use the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Bidirectional</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">drop-down list to indicate whether the language is written from right to left or not.
Click on the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Accept</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">button to save the newly added language.</text:span>

<text:span text:style-name="T8">Use the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Edit Language</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">button and the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Remove Language</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">button to change existing language codes or to completely remove them from the list of supported languages.</text:span>

<text:span text:style-name="T5">Swordfish</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">automatically adjusts the layout of all panels to display bidirectional text properly aligned to the right.</text:span>
Spell Checker
<text:span text:style-name="T5">Swordfish</text:span> provides two options for spell checking translations:

<text:span text:style-name="T5">Internal Spell Checker:</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">built in spell checker that uses dictionaries in Hunspell format from OpenOffice project.</text:span>
Aspell:

</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8">open source spell checker, included in most Linux distributions and with </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8">ports available for Windows and Mac OS X.</text:span>

<text:span text:style-name="T8">Use the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Default Spell Checker</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">option from </text:span><text:a xlink:href="#4.3.6. Options Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T8">Options</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="#4.3.6. Options Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a><text:span text:style-name="T8">menu to open this dialog:</text:span>

<text:span text:style-name="T8">Select the desired option and click on </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Accept</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">button to save your preferences.</text:span>
Configuration of Internal Spell Checker

<text:span text:style-name="T8">Select </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Internal Dictionaries</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">in </text:span><text:a xlink:href="#4.3.6. Options Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T8">Options</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="#4.3.6. Options Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a><text:span text:style-name="T8">menu and this dialog will appear:</text:span>

<draw:image xlink:actuate="onLoad" xlink:href="Pictures/10000000000001D30000014854F5259A.jpg" xlink:show="embed" xlink:type="simple"/></draw:frame> <text:span text:style-name="T8">Select a language from the top-left drop down list and the dictionary that you want to </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8">use for spell checking from the top-right drop down list.

Click on the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Add to List</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">button to store your selection in the list of configured language-dictionary pairs.</text:span>

<text:span text:style-name="T8">If the dictionary that you need is not included on the top-right list, click on the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Download Dictionaries</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">button to open this dialog:</text:span>
Browse the list of available dictionaries and locate the one you need.

Select the download server (Maxprograms.com or OpenOfice.org) and click on the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Download Dictionary</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">button to start the download.

If the dictionary you need is not listed, click on the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Refresh Dictionary List</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">button to check if there are updates in the selected server.</text:span>

<text:span text:style-name="T8">If necessary, use the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Proxy Settings</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">button to open a dialog for configuring a HTTP </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8">proxy server for accessing the Internet.</text:span>
Configuration of Aspell
Aspell is available on most Linux distributions.

You can download Aspell and dictionaries for Windows from </text:span><text:a xlink:href="http://aspell.net/win32/" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T8">http://aspell.net/win32/</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="http://aspell.net/win32/" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a>

<text:span text:style-name="T8">To configure </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Swordfish</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">to work with Aspell, select the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Aspell Dictionaries</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">option from </text:span><text:a xlink:href="#5.2.6. Options Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T8">Options</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="#5.2.6. Options Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a><text:span text:style-name="T8">menu and this dialog will appear:</text:span>

<draw:image xlink:actuate="onLoad" xlink:href="Pictures/10000000000001E300000170BD6D4092.jpg" xlink:show="embed" xlink:type="simple"/></draw:frame> <text:span text:style-name="T8">Enter the path to the Aspell executable in the top text box or use the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Browse...</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">button next to it to locate the program.
On Linux it is usually enough to type aspell in the text box.

<text:soft-page-break/><text:span text:style-name="T8">Check the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Use UTF-8</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">box if you experiment problems during spell checking.
This option is necessary in some versions of Aspell.

<text:span text:style-name="T8">Click on the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Refresh List</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">button to request Aspell a list of installed dictionaries.</text:span>
Select a language from the top-left drop down list and the dictionary that you want to use for spell checking from the top-right drop down list.

Click on the </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">Add to List</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T8">button to store your selection in the list of configured language-dictionary pairs.</text:span>
Auto-Save Settings
Swordfish<text:span text:style-name="T8"> can make backups of your XLIFF files at specified intervals while you translate.

Use the </text:span>Auto-Save Configuration<text:span text:style-name="T8"> option from </text:span><text:a xlink:href="#4.3.6. Options Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T8">Options</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="#4.3.6. Options Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a><text:span text:style-name="T8">menu to open this dialog:</text:span>

<draw:image xlink:actuate="onLoad" xlink:href="Pictures/10000000000000DC000000AE0E84EDA3.jpg" xlink:show="embed" xlink:type="simple"/></draw:frame><text:span text:style-name="T8">Check the Enable </text:span>Auto-Save<text:span text:style-name="T8"> box to enable this feature.
Set the auto-save interval in seconds and click on </text:span>Accept <text:span text:style-name="T8">button to apply and store your changes.</text:span>
XML Catalog
<text:span text:style-name="T5">Swordfish</text:span> uses the standard XML Catalog mechanism to resolve the location of DTDs and XML Schemas when dealing with XML files.

To customize the location of your DTDs or Schemas, select <text:span text:style-name="T5">Catalog Manager</text:span> option from <text:a xlink:href="#5.2.11. Advanced Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple">Advanced</text:a> menu and this dialog will appear:

<draw:image xlink:actuate="onLoad" xlink:href="Pictures/10000000000002DA0000014D06314F1B.jpg" xlink:show="embed" xlink:type="simple"/></draw:frame>Click on the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Add Entry</text:span> button to incorporate a new DTD or Schema to the catalog.
The following <text:soft-page-break/>dialog will let you select the referencing method that will be used for associating XML files to the new grammar:
Choose a referencing mechanism and click on accept button to display a dialog where you will enter the required details.
The following picture illustrates the entry dialog for PUBLIC identifiers.

<draw:image xlink:actuate="onLoad" xlink:href="Pictures/100000000000017F000000B378357FA0.jpg" xlink:show="embed" xlink:type="simple"/></draw:frame>Use the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Configure Entry</text:span> and <text:span text:style-name="T5">Remove Entry</text:span> buttons from the Catalog Manager dialog to edit existing entries or to remove them from the catalog.
XML Converter Configuration

Swordish<text:span text:style-name="T8"> can be used to translate almost any kind of XML files, but it is necessary to tell </text:span>Swordfish<text:span text:style-name="T8"> what elements and what attributes need to be translated.
This is done with the aid of configuration files.
Swordfish<text:span text:style-name="T8"> includes configuration files for these XML vocabularies:</text:span>
DITA 1.0 and 1.1
DocBook 3.x, 4.x and 5.x
SVG
Word 2003 ML
XHTML

<text:span text:style-name="T8">Use the </text:span>XML Converter Configuration<text:span text:style-name="T8"> option from </text:span><text:a xlink:href="#5.2.11. Advanced Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T8">Advanced</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="#5.2.11. Advanced Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a><text:span text:style-name="T8">menu to display the configuration dialog:</text:span>

<draw:image xlink:actuate="onLoad" xlink:href="Pictures/100000000000015600000189F2EEA9B3.jpg" xlink:show="embed" xlink:type="simple"/></draw:frame><text:span text:style-name="T8">Use the </text:span>Analyse XML Sample<text:span text:style-name="T8"> button to let </text:span>Swordfish<text:span text:style-name="T8"> examine an XML file and prepare a tentative configuration file for it.</text:span>
<text:soft-page-break/><text:span text:style-name="T8">Use the </text:span>Add Configuration<text:span text:style-name="T8"> button to create a custom configuration file.
When you click on it, this dialog appears:
Specify the name of the root element that your XML files may use.
Your XML files may use different root names and in this case it is recommended to create a configuration file for each possible name.
The root element name is used to name the configuration file.
After you click on the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Accept</text:span> button the following dialog will appear:
The configuration file must include a list of all elements that contain translatable text and elements that contain inline markup.
Elements not included in a configuration file list are ignored when an XML file is converted to XLIFF.
Click on the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Add</text:span> button to incorporate a new element to the list of configured elements.
When you click on it, the following dialog will appear:
Enter the name of the element in the top text box.
<text:soft-page-break/>Use the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Element Type</text:span> drop-down list to tell <text:span text:style-name="T5">Swordfish</text:span> how to treat it:
<text:span text:style-name="T5">segment:</text:span> create a new segment in the XLIFF file when this element is found.
The text contained in this element is translatable.
<text:span text:style-name="T5">inline:</text:span> add an inline tag to current segment.
The content of the inline tag is not translatable.
<text:span text:style-name="T5">ignore:</text:span> ignore this element and do not include its text in the XLIFF file.
If the element type is set to inline, you must indicate the kind of markup that this element represents using the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Inline Type</text:span> drop-down list.
Available options are:
image
pb (this element represents a paragraph break)
lb (this element represents a line break)
x-bold (this element contains text in <text:span text:style-name="T5">bold</text:span>)
x-entry (this element contains a database entry)
x-font (this element represents a font change in the document)
x-italic (this element contains text in <text:span text:style-name="T6">italics</text:span>)
x-link (this element contains a link)
x-underlined (this element contains <text:span text:style-name="T19">underlined</text:span> text)
x-other (this element contains markup of an unknown type)
If the element contains translatable attributes, enter the names of the attributes in the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Translatable Attributes</text:span> text box.
If it has more than one translatable attributes, enter the attribute names separated by ';'.
Optionally, use the options from the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Keep White Space</text:span> to indicate if the white space contained in the element is relevant and needs to be preserved or not.
Finally, click on the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Save</text:span> button to store the configuration.
Segmentation Rules

Swordfish<text:span text:style-name="T8"> uses </text:span><text:a xlink:href="#SRX" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T8">SRX</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="#SRX" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a><text:span text:style-name="T8">(Segmentation Rules eXchange) format to store the rules used </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8">when segmenting text.</text:span>
<text:span text:style-name="T8">An SRX editor is included in </text:span>Swordfish<text:span text:style-name="T8">.
It can be used to edit the SRX files stored in /srx folder of </text:span>Swordfish<text:span text:style-name="T8"> installation or to create new SRX files.</text:span>

<text:span text:style-name="T8">Select the </text:span>Segmenter Configuration<text:span text:style-name="T8"> option from </text:span><text:a xlink:href="#5.2.11. Advanced Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T8">Advanced</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="#5.2.11. Advanced Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a><text:span text:style-name="T8">menu to display the SRX editor </text:span><text:soft-page-break/><text:span text:style-name="T8">dialog:</text:span>

<draw:image xlink:actuate="onLoad" xlink:href="Pictures/10000000000001E40000014D484461DE.jpg" xlink:show="embed" xlink:type="simple"/></draw:frame>To customize an existing SRX file, select it from the list and click on the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Edit SRX File</text:span> button and the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Rules Manager</text:span> dialog will appear:<text:bookmark text:name="Rules Manager"/>
Every SRX file contains two sections:
<text:span text:style-name="T5">Language Rules:</text:span> sets of segmentation rules to be applied together
<text:span text:style-name="T5">Map Rules:</text:span> associates the language rules sets to a one or more source languages using regular expressions
Language Rules
The top part of the <text:a xlink:href="#Rules Manager" xlink:type="simple">Rules Manager</text:a> dialog deals with language rules.
To add a new set of rules, click on the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Add Language Rules</text:span> button and the following dialog will appear:

<draw:image xlink:actuate="onLoad" xlink:href="Pictures/10000000000001730000008F3EF337F9.jpg" xlink:show="embed" xlink:type="simple"/></draw:frame>Enter a name and click on the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Accept</text:span> button to incorporate a new, empty, set of language rules <text:soft-page-break/>into the SRX file.
To modify a rule set, select it from the top list and click on the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Edit Language Rules</text:span> button and the following dialog will appear:

<draw:image xlink:actuate="onLoad" xlink:href="Pictures/100000000000023C0000017DB3EFA841.jpg" xlink:show="embed" xlink:type="simple"/></draw:frame>The <text:span text:style-name="T5">Language Rules</text:span> dialog contains the actual rules used for breaking segments or for indicating exceptions, such as abbreviations.
You can add or modify rules using this dialog:

<draw:image xlink:actuate="onLoad" xlink:href="Pictures/1000000000000160000000C82C9F886A.jpg" xlink:show="embed" xlink:type="simple"/></draw:frame>Clear the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Breaks Segment</text:span> check box if the rule represents an exception, such as an abbreviation.
Enter a regular expression that represents the text that appears before a potential break point in the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Before Break</text:span> text box.
Enter a regular expression that represents the text that appears after a potential break point in the <text:span text:style-name="T5">After Break</text:span> text box.

SRX Specification details the regular expressions that can be used in an SRX file in section <text:a xlink:href="http://www.lisa.org/fileadmin/standards/srx20.html#Intro_RegExp" xlink:type="simple">1.2 Regular Expressions</text:a>.
Map Rules
The bottom part of the <text:a xlink:href="#Rules Manager" xlink:type="simple">Rules Manager</text:a> dialog deals with map rules.
To add a new map, click on the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Add Map Rule</text:span> button and a dialog will appear, asking for a map name.
Use the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Edit Map Rule</text:span> button to display a list of associations included in a map in the following dialog:

<draw:image xlink:actuate="onLoad" xlink:href="Pictures/10000000000001970000014FEA3C3F6F.jpg" xlink:show="embed" xlink:type="simple"/></draw:frame>Click on the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Add Map Rule</text:span> or <text:span text:style-name="T5">Edit Map Rule</text:span> buttons to invoke the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Language Map</text:span> editor dialog to associate one or more languages to a language rule set.

<draw:image xlink:actuate="onLoad" xlink:href="Pictures/100000000000018E000000B530A12C50.jpg" xlink:show="embed" xlink:type="simple"/></draw:frame><text:soft-page-break/>Enter a language pattern as regular expression in the top text box and select a matching language rule set from the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Language Rule Name</text:span> drop down list.
Click on <text:span text:style-name="T5">Accept</text:span> button to save your preferences.
Plugins
Swordfish<text:span text:style-name="T8"> is an extensible application.
It has a plugin architecture that permits interaction between </text:span>Swordfish<text:span text:style-name="T8"> and other tools.</text:span>

<text:span text:style-name="T8">Select </text:span>Plugin Configuration<text:span text:style-name="T8"> option from </text:span><text:a xlink:href="#5.2.12. Plugins Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T8">Plugins</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="#5.2.12. Plugins Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a><text:span text:style-name="T8">menu to display the </text:span>Plugin Configuration<text:span text:style-name="T8"> dialog:</text:span>

Click on the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Add Plugin</text:span> or <text:span text:style-name="T5">Edit Plugin</text:span> buttons to open the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Plugin Configuration</text:span> editor:

<draw:image xlink:actuate="onLoad" xlink:href="Pictures/10000000000001AD0000017880D4BDE3.jpg" xlink:show="embed" xlink:type="simple"/></draw:frame>Enter a description for the plugin in the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Plugin Name</text:span> text box.
The selected description will be used in the <text:a xlink:href="#5.2.12. Plugins Menu|outline" xlink:type="simple">Plugin</text:a> menu.
<text:soft-page-break/>Enter the application executable in the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Command Line</text:span> text box or use the Browse...
button next to it to locate the program.
Add parameters to the command line as necessary.
You can setup an optional shortcut for launching the plugin.
Check the Ctrl, Shift or Alt boxes as modifiers and type a shortcut character or select an option from the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Shortcuts</text:span> drop-down list.
Use the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Processes</text:span> option to tell <text:span text:style-name="T5">Swordfish</text:span> what data to pass to the plugin:
<text:span text:style-name="T5">Current Segment:</text:span> saves current segment as an XML file and passes the file to the plugin.
The XML file with current segment must be specified in the <text:span text:style-name="T5">Exchange File</text:span> text box.
<text:span text:style-name="T5">Current Document:</text:span> passes current XLIFF file to the plugin.
<text:span text:style-name="T5">Nothing:</text:span> does not pass anything to the plugin.
The plugin may return:
<text:span text:style-name="T5">Updated Exchange File:</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T5">Swordfish</text:span> waits until the plugin is closed and reads the exchange file.
The content of the exchange file is used to update current segment.
<text:span text:style-name="T5">Updated Document:</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T5">Swordfish</text:span> waits until the plugin is closed and then reloads current XLIFF file from disk.
Nothing:
Swordfish<text:span text:style-name="T8"> doesn't wait for any feedback from the plugin.</text:span>
Glossary
CAT

<text:span text:style-name="T8">CAT (</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T5">C</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8">omputer </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">A</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8">ided </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">T</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8">ranslation) is a form of translation wherein a human translator translates texts using computer software designed to support and facilitate the translation process.</text:span>
Character Set

A character set (sometimes referred to as code page) is a collection of characters that are associated with a sequence of natural numbers in order to facilitate the storage of text in computers and the transmission of text through telecommunication networks.
CSV

CSV (<text:span text:style-name="T5">C</text:span>omma <text:span text:style-name="T5">S</text:span>eparated <text:span text:style-name="T5">V</text:span>alues) is a standard file format used to store tabular data.
SRX

<text:span text:style-name="T8">SRX (</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">S</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8">egmentation </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">R</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8">ules e</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">X</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8">change) is an XML-based open standard published by </text:span><text:a xlink:href="http://www.lisa.org/" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T8">LISA</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="http://www.lisa.org/" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a><text:span text:style-name="T8">(Localization Industry Standards Association) </text:span>for describing the ways in which CAT programs and other language-processing tools segment text for processing.
TBX

TBX (<text:span text:style-name="T5">T</text:span>erm<text:span text:style-name="T5">B</text:span>ase e<text:span text:style-name="T5">X</text:span>change) is the open, XML-based standard for exchanging structured terminological data.
First released by LISA in May, 2002, TBX was submitted to the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) on February 21, 2007, for adoption as an ISO standard.
TMX

<text:span text:style-name="T8">TMX (</text:span> <text:span text:style-name="T5">T</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8">ranslation </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">M</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8">emory e</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">X</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8">change) is an open standard published by </text:span><text:a xlink:href="http://www.lisa.org/" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T8">LISA</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="http://www.lisa.org/" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a><text:span text:style-name="T8">(Localization Industry Standards Association).
The purpose of TMX is to allow easier exchange of translation memory data between tools and/or translation vendors with little or no loss of critical data during the process.
Translation Memory

Translation Memory (TM) is a language technology that enables the translation of segments (paragraphs, sentences or phrases) of documents by searching for similar segments in a database and suggesting matches that are found in the databases as possible translations.
XLIFF

<text:span text:style-name="T8">XLIFF (</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">X</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8">ML </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">L</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8">ocalization </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">I</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8">nterchange </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">F</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8">ile </text:span><text:span text:style-name="T5">F</text:span><text:span text:style-name="T8">ormat) is an open standard developed by </text:span><text:a xlink:href="http://www.oasis-open.org/" xlink:type="simple"><text:span text:style-name="T8">OASIS</text:span></text:a><text:a xlink:href="http://www.oasis-open.org/" xlink:type="simple"> </text:a><text:span text:style-name="T8">(Organization for the Advancement of Structured Information Standards).
The purpose of this vocabulary is to store localizable data and carry it from one step of the localization process to the other, while allowing interoperability between tools.
